Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 06:45AM tlew wrote: Hi Karen,  I had BMX with TE in June 2012. I had a C-section 4 years ago. The pain is comparable right after the surgery. I just wanted to lay in bed forever. Actually having a cut in the abdomen to me was a little worse and inconvient than the BMX. Almost every body movement is affected by your abdomen muscle. Walking, sitting, lifting, was all affected. But for the BMX, I just try to limit the use of my arms right after surgery and it was fine. With a C-Section I carried a very excited and happy feeling so the pain didn't feel that bad even though it was.  But the BMX, I was depressed and scared, so it made the pain worser than it really is. In truth, the pain is manageable and most people are up and around by the first week. It goes by quick. Just make sure you take the pain relievers and rest up.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 10:20PM tlew wrote: Wow I thought it was just me. I never had underarm odor prior to surgery. It lasted for a few months after surgery, now it has went away. I used an electric shaver a month after surgery. The shave is not as clean as with using a blade. But it's not suggested to use after removing lymph nodes.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2013 03:08AM tlew wrote: Hi, I had my nsm with IMF incisions last year. I had TE and did small fills within 4 months and then exchanged to silicone implants. I went a little larger than my originals. The results are good. With nsm there's a chance the nipples may not survive, so make sure the doctor explains that to you.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 10:29PM tlew wrote: Your timeline of events resembles mine. I was diagnosed last year at age 36 and had my bmx on 6/5/12. Reading your posts reminded me of the nightmare of getting BC. The BS told me the same thing, about chemo and age, etc... But they won't know the cocktail until after the surgery when you get your pathology report. I got thru it fine with lots of preparation mentally and physically. Lots of sisters on the forum can give you realistic advice. Once you get thru surgery, everything else will fall into place and life goes on. Good luck and will be thinking of you.
Posts.Title: 36 and just diagnosed...are you kidding me? adowney76 tlew

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 09:19PM tlew wrote: If you go to the young survivor coailtion website, you will see that breast cancer does occur in young women. I was diagnosed at 36 through a routine mammogram, which my gyn did not feel was even necessary at my age. If i did not do that mammo, i would walk around 4 more years not knowing. You are way younger than me, but I feel everybody still thinks BC happens mainly to older women or women with BC in the family. I was neither, so it caught me by surprise. Definetly get a second opinion and get answers. And keep a close eye on any changes and report to your doctor right away. I have a young toddler too, so I understand the feeling of having to be responsible for your baby and the need to stay healthy for them. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 10:48PM tlew wrote: I switched right before surgery as well. I had 3 opinions and had a difficult time choosing where to get it done. I opted for a surgeon who specialized in nipple sparing mx. I'm in NYC as well, I never looked into MSK, don't know why since they are rated top notch cancer center. Good Luck!
Posts.Title: Changing bs, hospital, right after diagnosis Sallyann tlew

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 09:38PM tlew wrote: I took 4 weeks off from work (office job). I definitely could of used more time. Just when i started to feel a little better, I had to start filling my TE. Ouch! I always felt tired and in pain especially for the first 6 weeks. I was constantly taking naps and it was never enough.The 1st week was the worst. But It got better once those awful drains came out. I made sure I took 15 min walks just so everything is circulating In my body and drink plenty of water, eat lots of good protein and fiber. that would help w/ the healing so you can get back to normal quicker. Good luck!
Posts.Title: this is an after surgery question anamerty gumshoe

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 10:03PM tlew wrote: The drains are definitely a pain when taking a shower and sleeping. But its manageable. I had mine out in 6 days. I'm not a drainer. It was a relief to take those suckers out. Just make sure you dont move without them moving with you. The tugging is going to hurt! Im so glad I don't have them with exchange surgery. 40 ounces is a good amount of fluid. The point is to flush out the anestestia and gets things flowing again.
